chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Paracetamol
chapter.summary: Covers prescribing information on paracetamol, including information on adverse effects, interactions, safety in pregnancy and breastfeeding, and general advice.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 3 months onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the contraindications and cautions for paracetamol?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• There are no contraindications to the use of paracetamol.
  • Prescribe paracetamol with caution (and consider a dose reduction):
    • If there are risk factors for hepatotoxicity and inadvertent paracetamol overdose, including:
      • Alcohol dependency.
      • Malnutrition.
      • Chronic dehydration.
      • Body weight less than 50 kg.
      • Severe liver disease — pharmacokinetics of paracetamol is altered in severe liver disease, and the hazards of overdose are greater in people with non-cirrhotic alcoholic liver disease.
      • Increasing age and/or frailty — a reduction of the clearance of paracetamol has been associated with increased age and frailty. In addition, elderly people have comorbidities and polypharmacy, which can further increase risk of inadvertent paracetamol toxicity and overdose.
      • The use of liver enzyme-inducing drugs (such as rifampicin, carbamazepine, and phenytoin) — see the section on Drug interaction for more information.
  • Avoid effervescent preparations of paracetamol where possible, particularly in people with hypertension, heart failure, and renal failure — if oral paracetamol is required in a person with swallowing difficulty, use paracetamol suspension in place of effervescent preparations (which contains up to 6 g salt in a 4 g per 24 hours dose).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Contraindications
  • The Summary of Product Characteristics (SPC) for paracetamol [ABPI, 2020d] and the British National Formulary (BNF) [BNF, 2020] do not list any contraindications for paracetamol.
Cautions
  • The SPC and the BNF advise caution in chronic alcohol consumption, chronic dehydration, chronic malnutrition, hepatocellular insufficiency, and long-term use (especially in those who are malnourished), but no dose reduction is advised for these groups of people [ABPI, 2020d; Joint Formulary Committee, 2020].
  • Caution is also advised in the NHS Borders Medication Safety Action Committee Medication Safety Bulletin [NHS Borders, 2012], the Leeds Teaching Hospital NHS Trust guideline Reducing oral paracetamol doses in adults [NHS Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, 2020], and the NHS Wales guideline Prescribing paracetamol in patients aged 16 and over [NHS Wales, 2018].
  • There have been documented reports of liver damage (one fatal) in people weighing less than 50 kg when given the standard dose (1 g four times daily) of paracetamol.
    • The Medicines and Healthcare Products and Regulatory Agency (MHRA) has reviewed the literature since these reports and concluded that the people in these case reports had pre-existing risk factors, such as chronic malnutrition or high alcohol consumption, which are known indications for considering a dose reduction of oral paracetamol.
    • Although the MHRA concluded that a person’s weight being less than 50 kg is not in itself an indication to reduce the dose of oral paracetamol, consideration should be given to lowering the dose in people with other conditions likely to pre-dispose them to liver damage from paracetamol. Low body weight is often an indication that the person may have other chronic conditions that increases their risk of toxicity [NHS Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, 2020].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What dose of paracetamol should I prescribe?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• The recommended doses of paracetamol for people aged 18 years and older are:
    • By mouth — 500 mg to 1 g every 4 to 6 hours as required (maximum 4 g in 24 hours).
    • By rectum — 500 mg to 1 g every 4 to 6 hours as required (maximum 4 g in 24 hours).
  • The recommended doses of paracetamol for children aged up to 17 years are shown in Table 1 below. These doses may be repeated every 4 to 6 hours if necessary (maximum of four doses in 24 hours).

  • Use clinical judgement to adjust the dose of oral paracetamol in people with risk factors for hepatotoxicity and paracetamol overdose, for example, people with liver disease and people with body weight less than 50 kg. If risk factors are present:
    • Consider reducing the total daily dose of paracetamol as follows:
      • Body weight 30–39 kg — prescribe 15 mg per kg per dose. The final dose should be determined on an individual basis (maximum of 60 mg per kg in 24 hours; use oral suspension if necessary).
      • Body weight 40–49 kg — prescribe 500 mg to 1 g every 6 hours as required (maximum 3 g in 24 hours, for example, prescribe 1 g three times daily).
      • Body weight more than 50 kg — prescribe 500 mg to 1 g every 4 to 6 hours as required (maximum 3 g in 24 hours).
    • Monitor liver function tests if increased. 
    • Advise the person that they have been prescribed a lower dose and explain the reason why.
      • Advise caution when using over-the-counter paracetamol-containing products; the recommended maximum total daily dosage must not be exceeded.
      • Explain that the lower dose of paracetamol may not be stated in the manufacturer's patient information leaflet.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Recommended doses of paracetamol for most people
  • These recommendations are based on the British National Formulary (BNF) [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020].
Recommended doses of paracetamol for people with risk factors for hepatotoxicity and paracetamol overdose

  • These recommendations are based on expert opinion in the NHS Borders Medication Safety Action Committee Medication Safety Bulletin [NHS Borders, 2012], the Leeds Teaching Hospital NHS Trust guideline Reducing oral paracetamol doses in adults [NHS Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, 2020], and the NHS Wales guideline Prescribing paracetamol in patients aged 16 and over [NHS Wales, 2018].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the adverse effects of paracetamol?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Adverse effects are rare with paracetamol.
  • Blood dyscrasias (including thrombocytopenia and agranulocytosis) have been rarely reported in people taking oral paracetamol, but it is not clear that these were directly caused by the paracetamol.
  • Other possible adverse effects of paracetamol include:
    • Common or very common:
      • Rectal — anorectal erythema.
    • Rare or very rare:
      • Rectal— angioedema, liver injury, skin reactions.
    • Frequency unknown: 
      • Oral — abnormal hepatic function, agranulocytosis, bronchospasm, rash, and severe cutaneous adverse reactions (SCARs).
      • Rectal — agranulocytosis, blood disorder, and SCARs.
  • Liver damage and renal damage (less frequent) can occur in people who have taken 10 g or more of paracetamol. Ingestion of 5 g or more may lead to liver damage if the person has risk factors for liver damage, including alcohol dependence, pre-existing liver disease, malnutrition, and the use of liver enzyme-inducing drugs (such as rifampicin, carbamazepine, and phenytoin).
    • Early symptoms of paracetamol overdose (seen in the first 24 hours) are pallor, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
    • Liver damage may become apparent 12–48 hours after ingestion, and symptoms include right subcostal pain and tenderness. In severe poisoning, the person may develop encephalopathy, haemorrhage, hypoglycaemia, and cerebral oedema.
    • Acute renal failure with acute tubular necrosis, strongly suggested by loin pain, haematuria, and proteinuria, may develop even in the absence of severe liver damage. 
    • People who have taken an overdose of paracetamol may require immediate hospital admission depending on the quantity of paracetamol taken and the presence of risk factors for liver damage. See the TOXBASE website or telephone the National Poisons Information Services (NPIS) on 0344 892 0111 for advice on when admission is required.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This information is based on the manufacturer's Summary of Product Characteristics (SPC) [ABPI, 2020d] and the British National Formulary (BNF) [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the key drug interactions with paracetamol and how should I manage them?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Drug interactions with paracetamol include:
    • Alcohol — excessive alcohol consumption causes severe liver damage when given with paracetamol. Also, paracetamol and alcohol can increase the risk of hepatotoxicity.
      • Manufacturer makes no recommendation.
    • Anticoagulants — the effect of warfarin and other coumarins may be enhanced by prolonged regular use of paracetamol, with increased risk of bleeding. Occasional doses have no significant effect.
      • Monitor international normalized ratio (INR).
    • Colestyramine — may reduce absorption if given within 1 hour of paracetamol.
      • Separate administration by 1 to 2 hours.
    • Domperidone and metoclopramide — may increase speed of absorption of paracetamol.
    • Liver enzyme-inducing drugs — the use of liver enzyme-inducing drugs (such as rifampicin, carbamazepine, and phenytoin) can increase the risk of hepatotoxicity.
      • Consider a paracetamol dose reduction.
  • See the electronic Medicines Compendium (eMC) or the British National Formulary (BNF) for a list of all possible drug interactions with paracetamol.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This information is based on the manufacturer's Summary of Product Characteristics (SPC) [ABPI, 2020d] and the British National Formulary (BNF) [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Can I prescribe paracetamol to a woman who is pregnant or breastfeeding?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Pregnancy
    • Paracetamol is the analgesic of choice for women who are trying to conceive or who are pregnant.
    • It can be used at the standard dose at any stage of pregnancy.
  • Breastfeeding
    • Paracetamol is the analgesic of choice for women who are breastfeeding.
    • Very small amounts of paracetamol pass into the breast milk, and these amounts are far below the doses that would normally be given to infants directly.
    • Seek specialist advice if:
      • The infant is pre-term or low birth weight.
      • The absorption, distribution, metabolism, or excretion of paracetamol may be affected by an underlying medical condition in the infant.
      • The mother is taking multiple medicines.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Pregnancy
  • Paracetamol has been used by pregnant women for many years without any obvious harmful effects on the developing baby. For this reason, it is usually recommended as the analgesic of choice for pregnant women [UKTIS, 2017a].
  • The UK Teratology Information Service (UKTIS) states that an association with an increased risk of any adverse fetal outcome following therapeutic paracetamol use in pregnancy remains to be proven [UKTIS, 2017b].
  • The manufacturer states that if clinically needed, paracetamol can be used during pregnancy. However, it should be used at the lowest effective dose for the shortest possible time and at the lowest possible frequency [ABPI, 2020d].
Breastfeeding
  • There is very little published evidence on the use of paracetamol during breastfeeding.
  • Evidence from five small studies identified by the UK Medicines Information (UKMi) showed that very small amounts of paracetamol pass into the breast milk and these amounts are far below the doses that would normally be given to infants directly [UKMI, 2020].
  • With the exception of one possible hypersensitivity reaction in a single case report, no adverse effects have been reported in breastfeeding infants whose mothers have taken paracetamol in over 50 years of use in the UK.
    • In the case report, a mother was given 1 g of paracetamol at bedtime for 2 days after which a maculopapular rash appeared on the infant’s chest and face. The rash disappeared 24 hours after the paracetamol was discontinued but reappeared when the mother was given another 1 g dose of paracetamol 2 weeks later [UKMI, 2020].
  • The manufacturer states that paracetamol is excreted in breast milk but not in a clinically significant amount. Available published data do not contraindicate breastfeeding with paracetamol [ABPI, 2020d].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What information and advice should I give to a person receiving paracetamol?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Advise the person and/or their parents/carers that:
    • If they have continuous pain, they should use paracetamol regularly (four times a day).
    • Paracetamol rarely causes adverse effects when used at the correct dosage.
    • There are other paracetamol-containing medicines available over-the-counter (OTC). The recommended maximum total daily dosage must not be exceeded.
  • Provide written information on paracetamol and pain management.
    • The British Pain Society leaflet Managing your pain effectively using “Over the Counter” (OTC) Medicines discusses the short- and long-term use of OTC analgesics and their associated adverse effects.
    • The NHS website (www.nhs.uk) has information on Paracetamol for adults and Paracetamol for children (including Calpol).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
